meta.content: Front Page; New York and Region
meta.name: online_sections

block.p: 700-Mile Border Fence Wins Senate Approval The Senate approved building 700 miles of fence along the Mexican border, fulfilling a demand by conservative Republicans to take steps to slow the flow of illegal immigrants. President Bush has promised to sign the bill, despite his push for a more comprehensive approach.

After Loss, Fund Will Close Amaranth Advisors, the $9.2 billion hedge fund that lost $6.5 billion in less than a month by making unwise investments in the natural gas markets, said it would liquidate and distribute the remaining assets to its shareholders.
A Bathroom Brawl in Chess After a player in the World Chess Championships was locked out of his private bathroom amid accusations of cheating, he refused to play, and the game was forfeited.
For When a Father Can't Be There Ashton Gardner, 6, with his Flat Daddy, a cutout that the Maine National Guard gives to families with a relative thousands of miles away.
Woodward Book Causes Stir The White House tried to dismiss the portrayal of Bush administration discord in Bob Woodward's new book, ''State of Denial.''
Michiko Kakutani's review of the book.

Nicaraguan's Comeback Trail Washington's old cold war nemesis, Daniel Ortega, is again smiling down from campaign billboards across Nicaragua. Now 60, he stands his best chance yet of returning to power in elections on Nov. 5.

The City of Light becomes a place of shadows and unexpected beauty at night. Alone in an elegant courtyard or in the quiet outside a shuttered brasserie, the visitor finds a Paris that will disappear at dawn.
The Culinary Awakening ''The United States of Arugula'' tracks the transformation of American gastronomy, from Julia Child and James Beard to Emeril Lagasse and Rachael Ray.

700-Mile Border Fence Wins Senate Approval The Senate approved building 700 miles of fence along the Mexican border, fulfilling a demand by conservative Republicans to take steps to slow the flow of illegal immigrants. President Bush has promised to sign the bill, despite his push for a more comprehensive approach.

After Loss, Fund Will Close Amaranth Advisors, the $9.2 billion hedge fund that lost $6.5 billion in less than a month by making unwise investments in the natural gas markets, said it would liquidate and distribute the remaining assets to its shareholders.
A Bathroom Brawl in Chess After a player in the World Chess Championships was locked out of his private bathroom amid accusations of cheating, he refused to play, and the game was forfeited.
For When a Father Can't Be There Ashton Gardner, 6, with his Flat Daddy, a cutout that the Maine National Guard gives to families with a relative thousands of miles away.
Woodward Book Causes Stir The White House tried to dismiss the portrayal of Bush administration discord in Bob Woodward's new book, ''State of Denial.''
Michiko Kakutani's review of the book.

Nicaraguan's Comeback Trail Washington's old cold war nemesis, Daniel Ortega, is again smiling down from campaign billboards across Nicaragua. Now 60, he stands his best chance yet of returning to power in elections on Nov. 5.

The City of Light becomes a place of shadows and unexpected beauty at night. Alone in an elegant courtyard or in the quiet outside a shuttered brasserie, the visitor finds a Paris that will disappear at dawn.
The Culinary Awakening ''The United States of Arugula'' tracks the transformation of American gastronomy, from Julia Child and James Beard to Emeril Lagasse and Rachael Ray.
